1.content: The sluggard is pelted with a dirty stone, and all men will speak of his disgrace.

2.content: The sluggard is pelted with the dung of oxen: and every one that toucheth him will shake his hands.

3.content: A son ill taught is the confusion of the father: and a foolish daughter shall be to his loss.

4.content: A wise daughter shall bring an inheritance to her husband: but she that confoundeth, becometh a disgrace to her father.

5.content: She that is bold shameth both her father and husband, and will not be inferior to the ungodly: and shall be disgraced by them both.

6.content: A tale out of time is like music in mourning: but the stripes and instruction of wisdom are never out of time.

7.content: He that teacheth a fool, is like one that glueth a potsherd together.

8.content: He that telleth a word to him that heareth not, is like one that waketh a man out of a deep sleep.

9.content: He speaketh with one that is asleep, who uttereth wisdom to a fool: and in the end of the discourse he saith: Who is this?

10.content: Weep for the dead, for his light hath failed: and weep for the fool, for his understanding faileth.

11.content: Weep but a little for the dead, for he is at rest.

12.content: For the wicked life of a wicked fool is worse than death.

13.content: The mourning for the dead is seven days: but for a fool and an ungodly man all the days of their life.

14.content: Talk not much with a fool and go not with him that hath no sense.

15.content: Keep thyself from him, that thou mayst not have trouble, and thou shalt not be defiled with his sin.

16.content: Turn away from him, and thou shalt find rest, and shalt not be wearied out with his folly.

17.content: What is heavier than lead? and what other name hath he but fool?

18.content: Sand and salt, and a mass of iron is easier to bear, than a man without sense, that is both foolish and wicked.

19.content: A frame of wood bound together in the foundation of a building, shall not be loosed: so neither shall the heart that is established by advised counsel.

20.content: The thought of him that is wise at all times, shall not be depraved by fear.

21.content: As pales set in high places, and plasterings made without cost, will not stand against the face of the wind:

22.content: So also a fearful heart in the imagination of a fool shall not resist against the violence of fear.

23.content: As a fearful heart in the thought of a fool at all times will not fear, so neither shall he that continueth always in the commandments of God.

24.content: He that pricketh the eye, bringeth out tears: and he that pricketh the heart, bringeth forth resentment.

25.content: He that flingeth a stone at birds, shall drive them away: so he that upbraideth his friend, breaketh friendship.

26.content: Although thou hast drawn a sword at a friend, despair not: for there may be a returning. To a friend,

27.content: If thou hast opened a sad mouth, fear not, for there may be a reconciliation: except upbraiding, and reproach, and pride, and disclosing of secrets, or a treacherous wound: for in all these cases a friend will flee away.

28.content: Keep fidelity with a friend in his poverty, that in his prosperity also thou mayst rejoice.

29.content: In the time of his trouble continue faithful to him, that thou mayst also be heir with him in his inheritance.

30.content: As the vapour of a chimney, and the smoke of the fire goeth up before the fire: so also injurious words, and reproaches, and threats, before blood.

31.content: I will not be ashamed to salute a friend, neither will I hide myself from his face: and if any evil happen to me by him, I will bear it.

32.content: But every one that shall hear it, will beware of him.

33.content: Who will set a guard before my mouth, and a sure seal upon my lips, that I fall not by them, and that my tongue destroy me not?

disclaimer: This book is an addition to the Old Testament. It is not found in the Hebrew or Aramaic texts, but are found in the Greek Septuagint and the Latin Vulgate.
